title: Małgorzata Peszyńska
summary: Małgorzata Peszyńska (born August 28, 1962)[1] is a Polish and American applied mathematician specializing in the mathematical modeling and computational solution of flows through porous media and their geological applications, including the effects of global warming on methane locked in permafrost.[2] She is a professor of mathematics at Oregon State University,[3] on leave as program director for computational and data-enabled science and engineering and computational mathematics at the National Science Foundation.[4]
